reviewText:
Placed on a pogo stick at the start of each level the only goal is to reach the end. Progress through the game and you will be confronted with new enemies, bosses and traps along with basic puzzle elements. Most were quite simple and more a matter of finding the item required to pass that area. Power-ups included rapid-fire for your weapon and boosts to pogo speed and jump heights.

Pongo is lighthearted and enjoyable enough but it's tough to recommend at full price. Enemies were colourful and quirky though levels seemed a little repetitive and didn't change colour schemes at all. Sometimes islands with power-ups were placed so far away from the objective the 10sec timer would expire before you could actually use them which seemed a bit pointless. Controls felt like they could be more responsive, often I found my self drinking ocean water instead of launching into the heavens but probably more issues with my throwaway keyboard to blame. Gamepad support unfortunately wasn't included at all.

Sounds all bad but I'll upvote the game as there is still fun to be had in the lovelyplanet-esque world. Just feels expensive for what's currently offered and personally didn't feel the urge to continue onward, some collectible items may have helped as a side objective. Would recommend waiting out a price drop or further tweaks to the game. Some ideas and a gameplay video are below.

reviewText:
I really wanted to like this game. The trailer reminded me of Lovely Planet, which I really enjoyed. There are a few issues with this game that push it into the 'not recommended' category for me.

The pogo mechanic is interesting, but it's clunky to charge up the jumps and time it just right when you're right at the edge of a platform. This isn't a huge deal in most levels because you have enough space to make it, but in a few levels (like 1-22) there is very little room for error as far as having max charge and jumping at the very edge of the platform.

Moving platforms are horrible. You lose momentum when jumping and it's very hard to time it correctly. Also, there is no visible way to tell where a platform is going to change direction, so with faster moving platforms, you end up in the wrong place or it throws you off the edge.

Level design is boring with long sections of running straight with larger islands connected by the aforementioned moving platforms. Enemies are no threat whatsoever and you can run past all of them, but the few times you are forced to fight, you quickly find out that combat is also terrible because you can't strafe fast enough to outrun things.

This game has a lot of potential and I'd love to see some thoughtfully designed levels in the future. I had a lot of fun with the speed power-up and I'd love to see some maps designed around it. I would also love it if you removed the running button and just made that the default move speed. Having the sprint key toggle off on you because you slowed down too much makes platforming annoying and unpredictable and having to hold shift to avoid that makes my hand tired.

If some of the issues are fixed, I would be happy to change this to recommended, but as is, I can't suggest that anyone spend $8 for this.

This game reminded me of my experience with Woodle Tree Adventure.  Get it on sale, get some cards, and if you like achievements, get those too.  Combined with nice graphics and amusing (but simple) gameplay, and this is one of the more memorable titles i've grabbed for a quarter or less.

reviewText:
Pongo! is a game about life. There are ups, downs and lots of geometric shapes that want to kill you for no adequately explained reason. Just as in real life, the best way through Pongo! is on a pogo stick, in fact, it is the only way. Luckily for you this game embodies the true American value of making sure everything in your possession also doubles as some sort of firearm so you can use your trusty stick to shoot down those dangerous coloured shapes.

There is a large gamut of challenging puzzles such as jumping on platforms, jumping on moving platforms, realising that the speed powerup continues to apply for as long as you are sprinting, jumping on platforms with trees on them, jumping on moving platforms with trees on them, figuring out you need to jump on a rock and use the bounce button, getting hit by enemies, branching pathways that don’t make a difference, branching pathways where one way leads to a dead end and of course the controls.

In addition to the puzzling challenges there is also a wide variety of enemies that appear throughout the game such as: Shooty Cube, Punchy Cube, Inanimate Cube, ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ Cheating Butterfly ♥♥♥♥, Helicopter Arms Easter Egg, Big Orange Kite and The Bounce Button.

All that said this was a pretty fun game and also a great streaming experience. 7 sproings / 13 pongos

Some notes to the dev if you are reading this:
Please for the love of god add a sound effect for when I deal damage to the enemies. I spent like the first hour of my play time thinking the hitbox for the punchy cubes were broken because they inexplicably take 3 hits to kill and there isn’t any indication that you are hurting them when the bullets connect. It was particularly bad for the first boss, I spent a lot of time shooting before I eventually found the super jump powerup and got away and then I think he blew up? Still not really sure what happened there.

It’s also a bit confusing as the levels are numbered 1 to 50 in the level select but in the menu in game are named as level 1-1 to 1-50. Does it go up to 50-50?

One of the songs either at the end or beginning (or perhaps that’s just the game taking its sweet time to load that one in particular) has a massive gap of silence. I personally really liked the actiony piece of music and didn’t really care for the two others (did I mention there is only 3 songs in this game, and they just cycle through like a playlist, it probably would have been better if they picked one of the 3 songs for each level and just looped it) although the whimsical one really did suit the tone of the game.

Ingredients:
1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar

6. 1 pinch salt

8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:
1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

If your looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if your looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:
1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:
1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

reviewText:
https://youtu.be/hfZgAsmzQgQ

In adversarial world of floating island and endless oceans your only means of survival is your hybrid pogostick / machine gun.  Hop from island to island while avoiding enemies and collecting power ups.

The actual gameplay is a considerable failure.  Because the level design doesn't require the use of smaller jumps it's always better to go for max height.  This is at odds with the jump power bar's inherited uncertainty of how much of a jump you'll get.

Enemies in the game can be shot with your pogo gun but it's faster and simpler to just rush to the exit and ignore everything else.  Resulting in the only challenge to the game being timing max power jumps which isn't enough to hold interest.

reviewText:
This game is definatly not the worst game I've ever plaid. Certain music tracks are incredibly awful, but for the most part the music compliments the gameplay.

The main pogo stick mechanic is implemented very well, and I personally havn't plaid any game with movement like this. My favorite thing to do in the game is collect the bounce power-up, climb to the highest point in the level, and bounce as high as I can and turn on bounce mode (which retains your jump hieght) and bounce like a meniac to the end of the level.

The game's biggest weaknesses are the enemies, poor collisions, and one or two bad music tracks. The enemies provide no threat but at least you're not required to kill them (because combat is kinda boring) . Somtimes you'll hit the side of a platform and get suspended in air and then gradually slide off. And like I said there are a few really bad music tracks, but for the most part it's ok.

All in all, the platforming is fun and the game is cheap. I think it's worth a buy!

reviewText:
I've unironically come to enjoy this game, much to my friends' concerns, but I've shut out their opinions. Pongo is fun.

Seriously though this game isn't a hidden gem, it has a crap load of issues. Akward controls mixed with first-person platforming? Check. Faulty level geometry collission and power-ups that have no pick-up hitbox meaning that you can't use them? Check. Bland visuals? Check. Royalty free, stock BGM that doesn't loop or transition properly? You betcha.

However despite all of these really blatant and intrusive flaws I managed to find enjoyment in this game. Something about beating a level with a jump that seems nigh-impossible because of how unreliable the collision and controls felt so massively satisfying. Like when I got stuck on a single level for probably an hour because of one jump that required precision timing and a passionate prayer to every god, goddess, and spiritual being known and unknown to mankind just to make, and then I made it, I felt like a champ. Only to die to the next jump.

Needless to say it made gave me something to do while I listened to podcasts. Best ~0.50 cent purchase ever.
